title: Expected "type annotations needed", but inferred unit type instead
body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

I tried this code:

```rust
fn main() -> serde_json::Result<()> {
    let v = serde_json::from_str("null")?;
    println!("{:?}", v);
    Ok(())
}
```

I expected to see this happen:
```
error[E0282]: type annotations needed
 --> src/main.rs:2:9
  |
2 |     let v = serde_json::from_str("null").unwrap();
  |         ^ consider giving `v` a type
```

Instead, this code compiles and outputs `()`, i.e. `v` is inferred to have type `()`.

The code continues to compile if `println` is removed. The inferred type can be confirmed with `type_name`:
```rust
fn print_name<T: core::any::Any>(_val: &T) {
    println!("{}", std::any::type_name::<T>());
}

fn main() -> serde_json::Result<()> {
    let v = serde_json::from_str("null")?;
    print_name(&v);
    Ok(())
}
```

The code stops compiling when `.unwrap()` is used instead of `?`.

### Meta
<!--
If you're using the stable version of the compiler, you should also check if the
bug also exists in the beta or nightly versions.
-->

Tested on current stable (1.60.0) and nightly (1.62.0-nightly (2022-05-09 88860d5474a32f507dde)) at https://play.rust-lang.org/.
